Abandoned
Add debug log here which helps in debugging issue.
nit: property
Why its treated as warning when we have single PSU. It should be "OK" with State set to "Disabled"  right?
if disabled, then health should always be OK
plan to populate this?
any comment?
template (Title & description) & explain the scope of change.

nit: Do we need to return the error here(messages::internalError(sensorsAsyncResp->res))? As we are already doing interface existence check at 1158. Control coming here means, Already that interface exist and failing to get data means, There some internal error.
Done
I like this idea but will this numbers match with PSU numbers?
no, It is Redundancy item count.

Isn't this need to be filled? Just a clarification.

I see its out of scope(Commit message has to clarify though) as here you are adding support only for get. So we are good as is also.
It should be filled, Fan redundancy populates this
Done
why is it hard coded to 1 is required for redundancy? Couldn't I need 2 PSUs in some systems for it to be redundant? Shouldn't this compare against minnumberneeded?
where is health-rollup determined? Does this get populated to the rest of the system?

Here health status indicates the health of psu redundancy but not the system.

Here is analyzing the health status based on known information, no special design for it in the system.

yes, but it needs to affect the health rollup. Probably needs health association on backend.. But thats probably outside of this patch.

Done
why is this separate from the rest of the health logic? This looks like it should be apart of the health logic above.
again.. why is this hardcoded?

psu redundancy need at least 2 PSUs to do redundancy.
Once has 2 PSUs, it is ok to do redundancy.
That seems like it should be variable based on platform/company. What if I have a system that can't run unless there are 2 PSU installed? Then 2 is not considered redundant.
ok, that means to create property in EM config on PSU minNumNeeded right?

Note: 1. There is command for end user to config redundancy at runtime. 2. Most important once redundancy is enabled, only one PSU is active. there is no situation like 2 PSUs are active and one is idle. End user could disable redundancy via command and make sure all the PSUs are at active.
There is no such case as you mentioned. Do we still need to provide the configuration?

I'd expect there to be a property like this: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/1751787a076983b8d75bb208597272482e4c657b/xyz/openbmc_project/Control/FanRedundancy.interface.yaml#L4

Is it ok by below 3 steps?

1. Add RedundantCount in xx-Baseboard.json
        {
            "RedundantCount": 1,
            "Name": "Power Unit Redundancy",
            "Type": "PURedundancy"
        },

2. Add RedundantCount property in PSURedundancy.yaml
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/#/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/36134/1/xyz/openbmc_project/Control/PowerSupplyRedundancy.interface.yaml

3. PSU-Manager service to read it to RedundantCount property from EM

There are 5 patches in total including internal psu-manager.
Please review them at the same time.

dbus-interface definition: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/#/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/36134/
saw this in the other review.. why is it +1? wouldn't minNumberNeeded == the count to make it redundant?
Done
populateFanRedundancy is very similar to populatePSURedundancy, is it possible to merge them?
good question

To simplify it. It is ok, I can see it is hard because of chassis association that is not required for PSU. Unless you want to make a function  like this:

template <typename Callback>
inline void
  iterateOverSubTreeControlPath(std::shared_ptr<SensorsAsyncResp> sensorsAsyncResp, const char* interface, Callback callback)
  crow::connections::systemBus->async_method_call(){
      iterate through dictionary
      callback(owner, path);
  },
  "xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper",
  "/xyz/openbmc_project/object_mapper",
  "xyz.openbmc_project.ObjectMapper", "GetSubTree",
  "/xyz/openbmc_project/control", 2,
  std::array<const char*, 1>{ interface });

Skip if you do not like it or does not follow bmcweb style.
can you abstract this callback into its own function?  It's pretty long, and the 80 character line lengths are hurting here.
Please don't use auto for these.
auto is used in other places in sensors.hpp. Can maintainer confirm that using auto is ok?

auto is acceptable in the cases that the value on the right allows you to easily tell what the lvalue is. This one is on the fence, as you need to know that get_if returns a pointer of the template type. I personally don't find these ones worth arguing about.

Given this might be platform or subsystem specific, this check should be done in the power supply daemon, and published to the same health dbus apis that other components do, then this can simply pull the status.
Yeah that would be nice if this used the health object, as some platforms loss of redundancy may be seen as critical
+1 to James comment, I just didn't know all the actual terms for the APIs you need to use.
avoid auto here.
This one I agree, as I have no idea what the value on the right is without inspecting the code.

This is looking at the response of one of the previous handlers, which can lead to inconsistencies if this handler gets handled before the other callback.  If you need the data from another callback, organize your code so you're explicitly called in the callback handler for that, and pass the info you need into your method.
The use_count == 1 below covers that I believe

Ah, gross.  Forgot we did that hack in this one.

Fine as is.
Why is this here?
Through reading the code I believe that PSU Status was never correctly implemented and we've been relying on input power == 0 to say the psu is disabled
is to cover the AC lost case.
Makes sense. Can we get it implemented correctly rather than propagating the wrongness forward?

it is not wrongness. PowerSupplies include all the connected PSUs, no matter AC lost or not.
But for PURedundancy, just need the AC on PSU.
Great, lets get that implemented in the PSU daemon, not in bmcweb.
nit You can pass sensorAsyncResp by reference
here is shared_ptr.

You can save some compute power if you pass it by reference. If you copy shared pointer than reference counter have to be incremented inside shared_ptr class. Reference counter is an atomic variable so it requires special synchronization

Here all are using shared_ptr for sensorsAsyncResp parameter, and even for other pointer parameters.
We should keep the same style right?

Please search and check.

Sorry for style. What I am suggesting is to change it only in one place in function parameters. Than in callback it have to be copied so the life of the object can be prolonged. I can see that it does not match the other function signature. I am sorry for it. Maybe a maintainers have more details why passing shared_ptr by copy in most of a function signature is used in sensors.hpp.
Anyway I would be very glad if you change it to reference. If you do not want to, I am fine with it. Thanks in advance and sorry for inconvenience.

When when not linking against pthread (which bmcweb doesn't) I believe the compiler will optimize out the refcount increment and decrement on this item, leading to the same code being emitted in these cases with optimization turned on.  Also, even if it didn't, we're talking 3 instructions, with no dependencies on other registers vs 1 instruction.  In the past, I've found those optimizations weren't worth arguing about, but I do think Jozef is right.

It'd be really nice if we had consistent style for these things,but today we don't, so IMO Kwin can change it if he likes, but it's fine as-is.
Please add an internal error (similar to what you do on line 1082.
nit Not consistent. On line 1050 you pass ec by value and here you pass by reference. Maybe change it to pass by value
You do not verify if findRedundantCount is found

+1 to the above.

In general the cleanest way to parse these out is to use std::vector<std::pair<...>> and simply loop.

There's a current effort to try to wrap this pattern in a utilities function to make it better, but it's not on master yet.
Please don't use auto here.  it obfuscates the integer type, and the fact that it's a pointer.

What's error to use auto?
Line 1265 used the same-thing

This needs to follow the current health design.  bmcweb should not be making decisions about whether or not the redundancy is healthy, that should be done in the PSU daemon, and have it publish the correct interface.

You mean to create a health property like below and handled by daemon right?
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/36467

We already have RedundancyCount property, it ok to judge the health status here like fan line 1298

Yes, create a health property.

"it ok to judge the health status here like fan line 1298"
This was done before the health design was complete or implemented, so it is grandfathered in.  Ideally someone would move that to the fan daemon as well, but new code needs to follow the new design.
nit by reference?
good catch!

Considering this is a copy.... It makes me wonder how this code worked in the first place.

Kwin, did you test this behavior?
Yes, it is better to use reference. but why say it is working currently using copy.

because inputPower will be a COPY of the element at PowerInputWatts key.

Writing to it means that the COPY will be changed, not the response, which means this code could've never worked, or I'm misreading something (or auto is actually pulling a reference here).

How did you test this condition?
DIdn't see a response to my old comment.
Please also include tests that involve making the Health object degraded, by pulling or unplugging power supplies.
This can't be hit?

continue does not make sense because response is set to error. Can you change it to return and remove a comment, please? Internal error means that this should not happen so comment is redundant. Thanks in advance
yeah I'm not really sure why its being set to error in the first place. just because one object is empty doesn't mean theres anything wrong?
right, this is not error
Okay, thanks. dbus allows to create interface that is empty (no property, no method). Than it should be possible, please, remove comment.
sensorsAsyncResp->chassisSubNode is Power, nevermind

targeted for Redfish 2020.4, is new thermal and power schemas see https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP-IS0015_0.8a.zip

PowerSupply will be its own resource. This makes this simplier
What's your point? Switch to this new schema right now in this patch?
